I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The lack of well-developed local currency bond markets was one cause of the maturity 
and currency mismatches that affected borrowers in the region, and that resulted in the 1997 
Asian financial crisis. At the time, overdependence on bank financing forced borrowers to take 
on excessive short-term foreign exchange exposure to finance long-term projects that could 
only  generate  local  currency  revenues.  This  created  two  “mismatch”  problems:  (i)  loan 
maturities became too divergent, to the detriment of both local creditors and borrowers; and (ii) 
the different currencies in which the loans were made became vulnerable to exchange rate 
volatility. A lack of international confidence in one local currency caused a rapid depreciation 
against the US dollar. A payments crisis then ensued, exacerbating the loss in confidence 
across the region through a “contagion” effect, and leading to banking and currency crises in 
several countries. Recent improvements in global macroeconomic conditions and the structural 
reforms implemented throughout the region have allowed most crisis-affected economies to 
recover and return to robust growth. However, despite recent growth, bond markets in the 
region remain largely undeveloped. 
 
2.  With this in mind, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations+3 (ASEAN+3)1 finance 
ministers  established  the  Asian  Bond  Markets  Initiative  (ABMI)  in  August  2003  to  boost 
development of local currency bond markets to help mitigate the double mismatch problem, and 
re-channel Asian savings within the region. Currently, the focus of the ABMI2 is on (i) expanding 
the number and diversifying the makeup of issuers on local currency bond markets, and (ii) 
developing an environment conducive and attractive to domestic and regional bond market 
participants. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported ABMI since its inception, 
particularly through the provision of technical assistance (TA). The ABMI also complements 
work done by other regional forums on bond market development, including the Executives’ 
Meeting  of  the  East  Asia-Pacific  Central  Banks  (EMEAP)  and  Asia-Pacific  Economic 
Cooperation (APEC).3 
 
3.  In  2005,  ADB,  at  the  request  of  the  ABMI  working  group  on  foreign  exchange 
transactions  and  settlement  issues  (WG3),  provided  assistance  through  the  TA  project 
ASEAN+3 Regional Settlement Linkage.4 In line with several recommendations of the study, 
ADB  was  asked  by  WG3  to  undertake  a  further  study  on  risk  reduction  in  clearing  and 
settlement, particularly on foreign exchange settlement risk5for cross-border bond transactions. 
 
                                                 
1  ASEAN+3 includes the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, 
Indonesia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet 
Nam) plus the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and Republic of Korea. 
2  The ABMI originally comprised six working groups but was reorganized in May 2008 and now comprises four task 
forces—task force 1: promoting issuance of local currency denominated bonds (cochaired by Thailand and the 
People’s Republic of China); task force 2: facilitating demand of local currency denominated bonds (cochaired by 
Singapore and Japan); task force 3: improving regulatory framework (cochaired by Malaysia and Japan); and task 
force 4: improving related infrastructure for the bond markets (Republic of Korea and the Philippines). The task 
forces will be complemented by the TA coordination team (cochaired by Brunei, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 
and Viet Nam). The overall work of the task force will be supervised by the steering committee, an apex body that 
oversees overall ABMI progress.  
3  EMEAP initiatives include enhancing the demand side for bond market development through Asian bond funds 1 
and  2.  APEC  initiatives  included  the  initiative  on  development  of  securitization  and  credit  guarantee,  and 
harmonization of bond market rules and regulations. 
4   ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for ASEAN+3 Regional Settlement Linkage. Manila (TA 6161-REG, approved on 
19 December). 
5  Foreign exchange settlement risk refers to risk exposure to cash payments and delivery of bonds arising during 
bond settlements on cross-border transactions.

2   
The report—Minimizing Foreign Exchange Settlement Risk in the ASEAN+3 Region,6—was 
completed  and  reported  to  the  WG3  meeting  in  November  2007.  At  that  meeting,  WG3 
members agreed that a group of experts (GOE) be established under the ambit of the ABMI to 
discuss several key issues outlined in the report, including issues related to cross-border bond 
transactions and settlement, as well as the feasibility of establishing a regional settlement 
intermediary (RSI). The objective is to improve the current arrangements and framework for 
cross-border bond transactions and settlement. The managing director general approved the TA 
concept clearance on 28 April 2006, under ADB’s 3-year knowledge products and service work 
plan 2007–2009.7 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  A securities settlement system can be broadly defined to include the set of institutional 
arrangements  for  confirming,  clearing,  and  settling  securities  trades  and  safekeeping  of 
securities. The development of a well-functioning settlement system—in which settlement of 
cross-border bond transactions is executed and completed in a timely, definitive and cost-
efficient manner—can contribute to more efficient bond markets. Such a settlement system can 
also minimize settlement risk and bring about greater financial stability. Securities settlement 
systems are therefore a critical component of bond market infrastructure. 
 
5.  The rapid growth of the ASEAN+3 bond market in recent years has also brought about 
an  urgent  need  for  more  efficient  clearing  and  settlement  systems  for  cross-border  bond 
transactions. Bond markets have become an increasingly important channel for intermediating 
fund  flows  among  borrowers,  lenders,  and  investors,  because  of  their  increasingly  active 
management of their securities portfolios. There is therefore a need to improve the region’s 
financial infrastructure to meet the needs of the growing bond markets.  
 
6.  Currently,  settlement  of  cross-border  bond  transactions  in  ASEAN+3  is  relatively 
inefficient. Most settlement intermediaries operate from time zones different from the Asian 
markets, which can lead to settlement risks, including liquidity and Herstatt risks.8 In addition, 
not all ASEAN+3 currencies can be settled through the Continuous Linked Settlement (CLS) 
Bank,9  forcing  them  to  utilize  a  correspondent  (third-party)  CLS  settlement-member  bank, 
thereby increasing risks and costs. For cross-border bond settlement in Asia (particularly for 
non-eligible CLS currencies), true delivery-versus-payment (DVP) and payment-versus-payment 
(PVP) is therefore seldom possible, resulting in higher costs for cross-border transactions and 
contributing to financial market instability. 
 
7.  To  address  these  important  issues,  the  report  under  the  TA  Minimizing  Foreign 
Exchange Settlement Risk in the ASEAN+3 Region suggested the establishment of an RSI that 
will provide both DVP and PVP functions. Three options10 for an RSI were identified: (i) an 
Asian international central securities depository, (ii) a pan-Asian central securities depository 
(CSD), and (iii) an Asian payments bank. It recommended that study of the feasibility of these

approved on 25 August]). 
7  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 29 July 2008.

does not simultaneously receive the currency it bought. 
9  There are currently only four Asian currencies (Hong Kong dollar, Singapore dollar, won, and yen) that are eligible

possible RSI options.

3
options be taken forward by market experts. As a result, ASEAN+3 endorsed the establishment 
of the GOE, which will comprise market participants such as custodians and national CSDs with 
expertise in cross-border bond transactions and settlement, to be nominated by each of the 
TF411 member countries, as well as global players, such as international CSDs and global and 
regional custodian institutions.  
 
8.  The approaches taken by the European market to promote greater market integration 
could provide valuable lessons for the ASEAN+3 region regarding harmonizing and coordinating 
the diverse interests of member countries and financial institutions. For example, the Giovannini 
Group,  established  in  1996,  comprises  a  group  of  financial  market  participants—including 
representatives  from  the  European  Commission,  banks,  brokers,  exchanges,  central 
counterparties,  and  CSDs—that  advises  the  European  Commission  in  making  decisions 
regarding the financial market. It specializes in identifying inefficiencies in the European Union 
financial markets and proposing practical solutions to enhance cross-border transactions. One 
of the Giovannini Group’s most important contributions is its report on barriers to cross-border 
clearing and settlements in the European Union and the strategies for their removal.12  
 
9.  The  Giovannini  Group  experience  suggests  that  a  similar  group  of  experts  can  be 
established in Asia to provide advice to governments on cross-border clearing and settlement 
issues as part of the region’s bond market development. The issues are complex, with various 
approaches  and  dependence  on  differing  institutional  arrangements,  necessitating  the 
promotion  of  cooperative  efforts  among  the  banking  sector,  regulators,  and  other  relevant 
stakeholders. The GOE will conduct a cost–benefit analysis of establishing an RSI for cross-
border bond transactions, and identify problems and propose recommendations on settlement-
related issues. 
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  TA  aims  to  assist  bond  market  development  and  to  promote  cross-border 
investment in domestic bonds in ASEAN+3. It will facilitate growth of and reduce settlement risk 
in cross-border bond transactions in ASEAN+3 region by supporting GOE activities. The GOE 
will study key issues related to cross-border bond transactions and settlement, including the 
feasibility of setting up an RSI to minimize settlement risk13 in cross-border bond transactions. 
The expected outcome would be for ASEAN+3 officials to make informed decision based on 
discussions related to feasible mechanisms for the settlement of cross-border bond transactions. 
This  will  lead  to  an  increase  in  cross-border  bond  transactions,  making  investing  in  local 
currency Asian bond markets more attractive. The TA will cover most ASEAN+3 countries, 
focusing on People’s Republic of China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet 
Nam.  
  
11.  The TA supports the regional cooperation and integration strategy of ADB’s Office of 
Regional Economic Integration to foster development of bond markets, build financial resilience, 
promote stability, and facilitate financial integration among countries in the region. 
 
                                                 
11 WG3 was reorganized in May 2008 and renamed task force 4 on improving related infrastructure for the bond 
markets (TF4). See also footnote 2. 
12 The report on cross-border clearing and settlement arrangements in the European Union may be found at 
http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/publications/publication1950_en.pdf. 
13 The scope of risks should be limited to those risks mentioned in the Giovannini report.

4   
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  Key factors in the study’s success will be (i) the commitment of the GOE; (ii) the depth of 
research, including consultations with market participants; (iii) the quality of discussions at GOE 
meetings; and (iv) the feasibility of the recommendations, driven to a large extent by the views 
and other inputs of the GOE. ADB will support GOE activities by conducting research (with 
support from TA consultants) into specific technical areas requested by the GOE, and by 
providing secretariat and administrative functions for the smooth running of GOE meetings 
including information dissemination among members, through the use of websites such as 
asianbondsonline.adb.org,  or  through  the  creation  of  a  specific  GOE  website,  and  media 
relations. However, ADB will not cover travel and accommodation costs for GOE members.  
 
13.  The research work of the GOE will proceed in two main strands: (i) evaluation of an RSI; 
and (ii) removal of settlement-related barriers to cross-border bond investment, including a 
review of laws and regulation for settlement and clearing. The content of each strand is further 
specified below. 
 
14.  Evaluation of an RSI. The GOE will select one or more RSI options for study from the 
list  in  the  report  under  the  TA  for  Minimizing  Foreign  Exchange  Settlement  Risk  in  the 
ASEAN+3 Region, and possibly others that may be suggested by TF4 or the GOE. It will 
investigate the details of the selected options, such as services offered, operations, ownership 
and governance, and likely participants. It will determine the legal, regulatory, operational, and 
other impediments to establishing and operating such an RSI, and review and assess the pros 
and cons. As far as possible, the GOE will quantify the benefits and costs of the selected RSI 
options, and will determine the likely investment and actions needed and a realistic timescale for 
its establishment. In the light of the foregoing, the GOE will assess the business case for the 
selected RSI options, and advise TF4 as to their overall feasibility.  
 
15.  The evaluation of the RSI should, in particular, take account of the extent to which it 
provides DVP and PVP in securities and cash settlements, and the associated benefits to 
market participants. The focus will be on improving cross-border settlement for the ASEAN+3 
bond markets. Where appropriate, in its evaluation of feasibility, the GOE will take into account 
benefits to the equity markets and foreign exchange markets as well. The GOE will also be 
invited  to  discuss  other  ideas  for  an  RSI,  such  as  provision  of  a  cross-border  central 
counterparty service and cross-border collateral management. 
 
16.  Identification of Settlement-Related Barriers to Cross-Border Bond Investment. 
The GOE will identify the main settlement-related barriers in ASEAN+3, including withholding 
tax and reporting issues, and document the extent to which these barriers exist in each country. 
These should include, but need not be restricted to, the barriers mentioned in the final report on 
minimizing foreign exchange settlement risk (para.14). It will assess actual inhibition of cross-
border bond investment by such barriers, and propose a road map for their elimination. 
 
17.  The GOE will also review laws and regulations relating to the finality of payments and 
securities settlements in each country, as relevant to cross-border bond transactions. 
 
18.  The study will also include a review of system capabilities and readiness of infrastructure 
and the supporting institutional arrangements in individual member countries for ASEAN+3 
linkages or establishment of an RSI.

5
19.  The study will propose nonbinding recommendations to the GOE, and provide TF4 with 
an appropriate road map for policymakers to remove identified impediments.  
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Investment  Climate  Facilitation  Fund14  under  the  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. Detailed cost estimates 
and a financing plan are in Appendix 2. Participating ASEAN+3 member countries will finance 
the costs of individual TF4 activities; GOE members will finance their respective costs relating to 
GOE activities. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  Initial  consultations  with  the  ASEAN+3  governments  were  conducted  within  the 
framework of ABMI Task Force 4, and the TA has been endorsed by them. ADB will be the 
executing agency for the TA, which will be administered and implemented by ADB’s Office of 
Regional Economic Integration, in close consultation with the ABMI TF4 member countries, 
particularly the Republic of Korea and the Philippines (the TF4 cochairs). ADB will supervise the 
work of the TA consultants.  
 
22.  Five international consultants and one national consultant will be engaged for a total of 
22  person-months  of  international  consultancy  services  and  12  person-months  of  national 
consultancy  services.  The  consultants  will  be  hired  and  engaged  by  ADB  as  individual 
consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from  time  to  time).  An  individual  consultancy  arrangement  is  suggested,  as  the  proposed 
experts will be assigned to different offices and/or locations to undertake research or serve their 
own counterpart(s), and will prepare individual reports and recommendations. The outline terms 
of reference for the consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
23.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  in  a  period  of  approximately  12  months  beginning  in 
December 2008. A series of GOE meetings will be held over the period to study and discuss the 
issues. The GOE will report regularly to TF4. Consultations with other market participants will be 
held as required. With these inputs, as well as those from government officials, a series of draft 
interim reports will be submitted to TF4 starting in February 2009. A final presentation to TF4 is 
expected in October 2009. The suggested outline of the final report is in Appendix 4. Upon 
completion, the report will be disseminated within ADB and on appropriate websites,15 with 
 
external publication of the report subject to approval by TF4 members. In addition, a conference 
will be held to disseminate and share the findings of the GOE interim and final reports with the 
rest of the capital market community.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $850,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Minimizing Foreign Exchange Settlement Risk in 
the ASEAN+3 Region: Support for Group of Experts, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Clearing and Settlement Markets Specialist (5 person-months) 
1.  The consultant is expected to have significant research as well as market experience in 
clearing  and  settlement,  and  extensive  operational  knowledge  of  clearing  and  settlement 
practices in financial markets. The consultant will provide overall guidance and coordinate with 
the other consultants to incorporate their views into the requested reports. The consultant will 
undertake tasks mainly related to the evaluation of the regional settlement intermediary (RSI) 
and oversee work on removal of settlement-related barriers. They will:  
 
(i)  Liaise closely with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the chair and vice-
chairs of the group of experts (GOE) and task force 4 on improving related 
infrastructure for the bond markets (TF4); organize, supervise, and coordinate 
the work of the other consultants; ensure that research is in line with the direction 
set down by the GOE and is of the required quality; and ensure that deliverables 
are delivered on time and within budget. 
(ii)  Assess  the  business  case  for  the  selected  RSI  options  and  provide 
recommendations on their overall feasibility. 
(iii)  Provide overall guidance and advice regarding the identification and removal of 
settlement-related  barriers.  Coordinate  with  other  consultants  to  ensure 
completion of the report. 
(iv)  Make nonbinding recommendations to GOE regarding future actions, which may 
include recommendations for further detailed study of some issues. 
(v)  Conduct regional workshops on improving clearing and settlement infrastructure 
for cross-border bond settlements.  
(vi)  With  the  assistance  of  the  other consultants,  prepare  all  reports  (discussion 
paper, and inception, interim and final reports) and make presentations. 
(vii)  Participate  in  GOE  meetings,  ASEAN+3  task  force  meetings,  subcommittee 
meetings,  and  a  regional  conference  on  improving  clearing  and  settlement 
infrastructure for cross-border bond settlements.  
(viii)  Perform other tasks as reasonably requested by ADB. 
 
2.  Clearing and Settlement and Legal Specialist (5 person-months) 
2.  The consultant is expected to have significant market experience in the clearing and 
settlement of bonds and possess extensive knowledge of clearing and settlement practices in 
financial markets. They are also expected to have significant legal experience in the area of 
cross-border clearing and settlement practices in a range of markets in the ASEAN+3 region. 
They will: 
 
(i)  Investigate  the  details  around  the  selected  RSI  option  (services  offered, 
operations, ownership and governance, likely participants, etc.) recommended 
for study by the GOE (from the list in the final report of the TA for Minimizing 
Foreign Exchange Settlement Risk in the ASEAN+3 Region, plus others that may 
be suggested by TF4 or GOE) 
(ii)  Assess the legal impacts on benefits and costs of the selected RSI options, 
based on information to be provided by GOE members.

(iii)  Review laws and regulations relevant to payments or securities settlements in 
each  country,  as  well  as  cross-border  payments  and  securities  settlements, 
through requests for information from national GOE members. 
(iv)  Identify the legal and regulatory issues related to the RSI options, assess the 
feasibility of the options, and make recommendations with respect to the legal 
and governance structure. 
(v)  Make recommendations regarding and prioritize the needed or desirable legal 
and regulatory changes to permit the functioning of the RSI option. 
(vi)  Assess  the  business  case  for  the  selected  RSI  options  and  provide 
recommendations on their overall feasibility. 
(vii)  Assist the clearing and settlement markets specialist in preparing a discussion 
paper; making presentations; and preparing consolidated inception, interim, and 
final reports. 
(viii)  Assist the collateral and foreign exchange specialist with legal issues related to 
cross-border collateral and foreign exchange. 
(ix)  Participate in GOE meetings and a regional conference on improving clearing 
and settlement infrastructure for cross-border bond settlements  
(x)  Perform other tasks as reasonably requested by ADB. 
 
3.  Clearing and Settlement (RSI function) Specialist (4 person-months) 
3.  The consultant is expected to have significant market experience in the clearing and 
settlement of bonds and possess extensive knowledge of clearing and settlement practices in 
financial markets. In particular, they are expected to provide information regarding some leading 
cases in other regions, particularly in Europe. They will: 
 
(i)  Provide analysis of some leading cases in other regions, particularly Europe, that 
need to be referred to in considering RSI options.  
(ii)  Investigate the details of the selected RSI option (services offered, operations, 
ownership and governance, likely participants, etc.) recommended for study by 
the  GOE  (from  the  list  in  the  final  report  of  the  TA  for  Minimizing  Foreign 
Exchange Settlement Risk in the ASEAN+3 Region, plus others that may be 
suggested by TF4 or GOE).  
(iii)  Quantify the benefits and costs of the selected RSI options. 
(iv)  Determine the likely investments and actions needed and a realistic timescale for 
setting up such an RSI. 
(v)  Assess  the  business  case  for  the  selected  RSI  options  and  provide 
recommendations on their overall feasibility. 
(vi)  Assist the clearing and settlement markets specialist in preparing a discussion 
paper; making presentations; and preparing consolidated inception, interim, and 
final reports. 
(vii)  Participate in GOE meetings and a regional conference on improving clearing 
and settlement infrastructure for cross-border bond settlements  
(viii)  Perform other tasks as reasonably requested by ADB. 
 
4.  Clearing and Settlement (Collateral and Foreign Exchange) Specialist (4 
person-months) 
4.  The consultant is expected to have significant market experience in the clearing and 
settlement of bonds and possess extensive operational knowledge of clearing and settlement

practices in financial markets. The consultant will be mainly involved in the study of additional 
RSI functions, such as cross-border collateral and payment-versus-payment (PVP). They will: 
 
(i)  Identify clearing and settlement issues related to additional RSI functions such as 
cross-border collateral and PVP.  
(ii)  Conduct a feasibility study of additional RSI functions and assess the business 
case  for  selected  additional  RSI  functions  that  can  be  included  in  the 
recommendations. 
(iii)  Assist the clearing and settlement markets specialist in preparing a discussion 
paper; making presentations; and preparing consolidated inception, interim, and 
final reports. 
(iv)  Participate in GOE meetings and a regional conference on improving clearing 
and settlement infrastructure for cross-border bond settlements.  
(v)  Support the work of GOE subcommittee A.  
(vi)  Perform other tasks as reasonably requested by ADB. 
 
5.  Clearing  and  Settlement  (Regulatory  and  Trade  Practice)  Specialist  (4 
person-months) 
5.  The consultant is expected to have significant market experience in the clearing and 
settlement of bonds and possess extensive operational knowledge of clearing and settlement 
practices in financial markets. The consultant will be mainly involved in the tasks relating to the 
identification of settlement-related barriers. They will: 
 
(i)  Identify  the  main  clearing  and  settlement-related  barriers  in  ASEAN+3  and 
document the extent to which these barriers exist in each of these countries. The 
research should include barriers relating to withholding tax and reporting issues, 
and other barriers mentioned in the final report on the TA for Minimizing Foreign 
Exchange Settlement Risk in the ASEAN+3 Region. 
(ii)  Assess the extent to which such barriers actually inhibit cross-border investment. 
(iii)  Propose a road map to TF4 for elimination of these barriers. 
(iv)  Assist the clearing and settlement markets specialist in preparing a discussion 
paper; making presentations; and preparing consolidated inception, interim, and 
final reports. 
(v)  Participate in GOE meetings and a regional conference on improving clearing 
and settlement infrastructure for cross-border bond settlements.  
(vi)  Support the work of GOE subcommittee B.  
(vii)  Perform other tasks as reasonably requested by ADB. 
 
B.  National Consultant 
6.  Project Coordinator (12 person-months). The project coordinator will have adequate 
experience  in  project  management  to  assist  ADB  and  the  international  consultants.  The 
consultant will: 
(i)  Assist ADB and the international consultants in the coordination and lending of 
logistical support for the arrangement of GOE meetings, and provide secretariat 
support to the GOE and its members. 
(ii)  Assist in the dissemination of information among members, and in the design 
and maintenance of the GOE website, and manage media relations. 
(iii)  Assist in designing and conducting the regional conference and seminars.

(v)  Provide research and technical assistance to international consultants in the

(vi)  Submit a status report on the project every 2 months and be responsible for

E.  Remaining Issues  
1.  Possible options for the RSI model 
a.  Linkage with central banks. In most market in the region, government 
bonds are settled by the central banks. It is desirable to discuss with 
central bank and encourage them for linkup. 
  
b.  Equity transaction function. To seek economy of scale and scope, it is 
desirable to include equity transactions in the region. However, this needs 
to have more detail research since equity transaction involves various 
corporate actions, which can be different from country to country. 
2.  Standardization  and  harmonization  of  regulations  and  trade  practices  in  the 
region. Harmonization of regulations and trade practices are the key for creating 
the  regional  bond  market.  The  governments  need  to  harmonize  regulations. 
Besides, market participants themselves should cooperate to standardize and 
harmonize market practices in transaction and contracts.  
3.  Institutionalization of private–public sector dialogue in the region. The GOE was 
the first region-wide collective action to express their opinion to the governments 
under the framework of ASEAN+3. It is important that the private sector and the 
governments continue to work together, and to do so, it is necessary to maintain 
the  framework  of  regular  consultation  between  private  sector  and  the 
governments.
